title: Get Started with affectOU
text: univariate affect process, stochastic differential equation OU process : dX(t)=Œ∏(Œº‚àíX(t))dt+Œ≥dW(t)d{X}(t) = {\theta}({\mu} - {X}(t))dt + {\gamma} \, d{W}(t) dX(t)=Œ∏(Œº‚àíX(t))dt+Œ≥dW(t)d{X}(t) = {\theta}({\mu} - {X}(t))dt + {\gamma} \, d{W}(t) , parameters represent: Œ∏ (theta): Attractor strength‚Äîquickly affect returns baseline Œº (mu): Attractor location‚Äîbaseline ‚Äúset point‚Äù affect Œ≥ (gamma): Diffusion coefficient‚Äîintensity random perturbations Create simple one-dimensional model default parameters: Specify custom parameters represent, example, process moderate mean-reversion (Œ∏\theta = 0.5), positive baseline (Œº\mu = 1), unit diffusion (Œ≥\gamma = 1):
code: model <- affectOU() model #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ 1D Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ #> dX(t) = Œ∏(Œº ‚àí X(t))dt + Œ≥ dW(t) #>  #> Œ∏ = 0.500, Œº = 0.000, Œ≥ = 1.000, œÉ = |Œ≥| = 1.000 model <- affectOU(theta = 0.5, mu = 1, gamma = 1) model #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ 1D Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ #> dX(t) = Œ∏(Œº ‚àí X(t))dt + Œ≥ dW(t) #>  #> Œ∏ = 0.500, Œº = 1.000, Œ≥ = 1.000, œÉ = |Œ≥| = 1.000

title: Get Started with affectOU
text: OU framework extends naturally multiple affect dimensions (e.g., valence arousal). d-dimensional process: dùêó(t)=ùöØ(ùõç‚àíùêó(t))dt+ùö™dùêñ(t)d\mathbf{X}(t) = \boldsymbol{\Theta}(\boldsymbol{\mu} - \mathbf{X}(t))dt + \boldsymbol{\Gamma} \, d\mathbf{W}(t) default 2D model uncoupled dynamics (diagonal ùöØ\boldsymbol{\Theta} ùö™\boldsymbol{\Gamma}) identical parameters across dimensions: Create uncoupled 2D model different parameters dimension: , use update() modify existing model without recreating scratch. coupled dynamics dimensions influence , use non-diagonal ùöØ\boldsymbol{\Theta} matrix:
code: model_2d <- affectOU(ndim = 2) model_2d #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ 2D Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ #> dX(t) = Œò(Œº ‚àí X(t))dt + Œì dW(t) #>  #> Œº = [0.000, 0.000] #>  #> Œò: #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]  0.5  0.0 #> [2,]  0.0  0.5 #>  #> Œì: #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]    1    0 #> [2,]    0    1 #>  #> Œ£ = ŒìŒì·µÄ: #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]    1    0 #> [2,]    0    1 model_2d <- update(model_2d,   theta = diag(c(0.5, 0.3)), # Different regulation speeds   mu = c(0, 1), # Different baselines   gamma = diag(c(1, 0.8)) # Different diffusion levels ) theta_coupled <- matrix(c(   0.5, 0.1,   0.2, 0.3 ), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE)  model_coupled <- update(model_2d,   theta = theta_coupled )

title: Get Started with affectOU
text: simulate() generates trajectories using Euler-Maruyama discretization: Simulation settings can customized:
code: sim <- simulate(model) sim <- simulate(   model,   nsim = 1, # Number of replications   dt = 0.01, # Integration time step   stop = 100, # Total simulation time   save_at = 0.1, # Output sampling interval   seed = 42 # For reproducibility )

title: Get Started with affectOU
text: Simulated data can explored various ways:
code: # Time series trajectory (default) plot(sim)  # Distribution of affect values plot(sim, type = "histogram")  # Autocorrelation function with theoretical overlay plot(sim, type = "acf")  # Phase portrait (lag-1 relationship) plot(sim, type = "phase")

title: Get Started with affectOU
text: Generate multiple independent realizations setting nsim > 1:
code: sim <- simulate(model, nsim = 3) plot(sim, type = "time")

title: Get Started with affectOU
text: Simulated data can extracted different formats:
code: # Directly from the simulation object data <- sim$data # 3D array (time √ó dimension √ó simulation) # Using head() or tail() head(sim, n = 3) #>   time dim sim    value #> 1 0.00   1   1 1.000000 #> 2 0.01   1   1 1.056281 #> 3 0.02   1   1 1.083456 # As a list of data frames (one per simulation) sim_list <- as.list(sim) head(sim_list[[1]], n = 3) #>   time     dim1 #> 1 0.00 1.000000 #> 2 0.01 1.056281 #> 3 0.02 1.083456 # As a data frame (long or wide format) sim_df <- as.data.frame(sim) head(sim_df, n = 3) #>   time dim sim    value #> 1 0.00   1   1 1.000000 #> 2 0.01   1   1 1.056281 #> 3 0.02   1   1 1.083456 # As a 3D array (time √ó dimension √ó simulation) sim_array <- as.array(sim) dim(sim_array) #> [1] 10001     1     3 # As a matrix (time √ó dimension) sim_matrix <- as.matrix(sim) head(sim_matrix, n = 3) #>      time dim sim    value #> [1,] 0.00   1   1 1.000000 #> [2,] 0.01   1   1 1.056281 #> [3,] 0.02   1   1 1.083456

title: Get Started with affectOU
text: equation() renders model‚Äôs stochastic differential equation multiple formats, offering plain text, LaTeX, R expression, code output. evaluated parameters:
code: cat(equation(model)) #> dX(t) = theta * (mu - X(t)) dt + gamma dW(t) #>  #> where: #>   theta = 0.5 #>   mu    = 1 #>   gamma = 1 #>   sigma = 1 cat(equation(model, inline = TRUE)) #> dX(t) = 0.5 * (1 - X(t)) dt + 1 dW(t)

title: Get Started with affectOU
text: fit() estimates OU parameters univariate time series using maximum likelihood:  See plot() details available diagnostics interpretations.
code: # Generate data from known parameters true_model <- affectOU(theta = 0.5, mu = 0, sigma = 1) sim <- simulate(true_model, dt = 0.01, stop = 500, save_at = 0.1)  # Extract the simulated data data <- as.data.frame(sim)  # Fit the model fitted <- fit(true_model, data = data$value, times = data$time) fitted #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Fitted 1D Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ #> 5001 data points (dt ‚âà 0.100) #> Œ∏ = 0.443, Œº = 0.019, Œ≥ = 1.002 #> Log-likelihood: -1237.784 #> RMSE: 0.310 # Residuals over time plot(fitted, type = "residuals")

title: Affect Characteristics Implied by the OU Process
text: perturbations, affect returns toward baseline Œº\mu rate determined Œ∏\theta (stable, unidimensional systems). High Œ∏\theta indicates rapid regulation; low Œ∏\theta indicates emotional inertia.
code: model <- affectOU(theta = diag(c(5.0, 0.5)), initial_state = 3) sim <- simulate(model, seed = 123, stop = 20) plot(sim,   by_dim = FALSE,   main = "Mean Reversion Depends on Œ∏",   sub = c("Fast Regulation (Œ∏ = 5.0)", "Slow Regulation (Œ∏ = 0.5)") )

title: Affect Characteristics Implied by the OU Process
text: relaxation time œÑ=1/Œ∏\tau = 1/\theta characteristic time scale OU process‚Äîtime expected deviation shrink 1/e‚âà36.8%1/e \approx 36.8\%. half-life t1/2=ln2‚ãÖœÑt_{1/2} = \ln 2 \cdot \tau marks 50% point. Effects decay exponentially: two œÑ\tau, 13.5% remains; three œÑ\tau, 5%.   ACF equals 1/e1/e relaxation time 0.50.5 half-life. Slow regulation means longer persistence higher autocorrelation. See relaxation() details concept interpretations.
code: model <- affectOU(theta = 0.5, mu = 0, gamma = 1) relaxation(model) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Relaxation time of 1D Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> Half-life (t‚ÇÅ/‚ÇÇ): 1.386 time units #> Relaxation time (œÑ): 2 time units #>  #> Time for perturbation to decay to: #>      50%     37%     14%      5%      1% #>    1.386   2.000   4.000   6.000  10.000 # Simulate with more time points for accurate ACF sim <- simulate(model, stop = 10000, dt = 0.01, save_at = 0.01) plot(sim, type = "acf", lag.max = 10)

title: Affect Characteristics Implied by the OU Process
text: parameter Œ≥\gamma controls magnitude random perturbations‚Äîemotional reactivity environmental fluctuations.   Higher Œ≥\gamma produces larger fluctuations around attractor.
code: model <- affectOU(theta = 0.5, mu = 0, gamma = diag(c(0.3, 1.5))) sim <- simulate(model, seed = 456, stop = 20) plot(sim,   by_dim = FALSE,   sub = c("Low Reactivity (Œ≥ = 0.3)", "High Reactivity (Œ≥ = 1.5)"),   main = "Effect of Reactivity on Fluctuation Magnitude", ylim = c(-4, 4) )

title: Affect Characteristics Implied by the OU Process
text: sign Œ∏\theta determines qualitative behaviour: Œ∏>0\theta > 0: Stable. Mean-reverting around Œº\mu. Affect fluctuates within bounded range. Œ∏‚âà0\theta \approx 0: Random walk. attractor; variance grows time. Affect drifts without returning. Œ∏<0\theta < 0: Unstable. Exponential divergence Œº\mu. Small perturbations amplify.
code: model <- affectOU(theta = diag(c(0.5, 0.01, -0.3))) sim <- simulate(model, stop = 100, seed = 43) plot(sim,   ylim = c(-10, 10), by_dim = FALSE,   main = "Affect Dynamics of Different Stability Regimes",   sub = c("Œ∏ > 0 (stable)", "Œ∏ ‚âà 0 (random walk)", "Œ∏ < 0 (unstable)") )

title: Affect Characteristics Implied by the OU Process
text: multiple dimensions, stability depends eigenvalues ùöØ\boldsymbol{\Theta}. Three cases arise: Real positive eigenvalues: Smooth exponential decay toward ùõç\boldsymbol{\mu}. dimensions settle without oscillation. Complex eigenvalues positive real parts: Damped oscillations. Dimensions rotate around ùõç\boldsymbol{\mu} phase space, spiralling inward. can represent cyclical affect patterns. eigenvalue zero negative real part: system non-stationary. Affect diverges time ‚Äì either drifting monotonically oscillating growing amplitude, depending whether eigenvalues real complex.    oscillatory case shows rotation phase space, reflecting imaginary component eigenvalues. affect dynamics, represent alternating patterns dimensions (e.g., valence arousal cycling together).
code: # Real eigenvalues: smooth decay theta_real <- matrix(c(0.5, 0.1, 0.1, 0.5), 2, byrow = TRUE) eigen(theta_real)$values #> [1] 0.6 0.4  # Complex eigenvalues: oscillatory decay theta_complex <- matrix(c(0.5, -0.4, 0.4, 0.5), 2) eigen(theta_complex)$values #> [1] 0.5+0.4i 0.5-0.4i seed <- 123 sim_real <- simulate(   affectOU(theta = theta_real, mu = 0, sigma = .1),   stop = 50, seed = seed ) sim_complex <- simulate(   affectOU(theta = theta_complex, mu = 0, sigma = .1),   stop = 50, seed = seed ) plot(sim_real, type = "phase", main = "Real eigenvalues") plot(sim_complex, type = "phase", main = "Complex eigenvalues")

title: Affect Characteristics Implied by the OU Process
text: multivariate models, -diagonal elements ùöØ\boldsymbol{\Theta} capture cross-regulation dimensions. ùöØ=[Œ∏11Œ∏12Œ∏21Œ∏22]=[self-regulation dim 1influence dim 2 dim 1influence dim 1 dim 2self-regulation dim 2]\boldsymbol{\Theta} = \begin{bmatrix} \theta_{11} & \theta_{12} \\ \theta_{21} & \theta_{22} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \text{self-regulation dim 1} & \text{influence dim 2 dim 1} \\ \text{influence dim 1 dim 2} & \text{self-regulation dim 2} \end{bmatrix}     positive entry Œ∏21\theta_{21} means dimension 1 deviates attractor, pushes dimension 2 opposite direction: dimension 1 baseline, dimension 2 pushed , vice versa. creates interdependent dynamics visible phase portrait.
code: # Dimension 1's deviations from baseline push dimension 2 in the opposite direction theta_2d <- matrix(c(   0.5, 0.0,   2, 0.5 ), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE)  model_2d <- affectOU(theta = theta_2d, mu = 0, gamma = 1) sim_2d <- simulate(model_2d, seed = 102) plot(sim_2d, by_dim = FALSE, main = "Coupled Trajectories", xlim = c(0, 20)) plot(sim_2d, type = "phase", main = "Phase Portrait")

title: Affect Characteristics Implied by the OU Process
text: -diagonal elements ùö™\boldsymbol{\Gamma} create correlated noise dimensions. can lead synchronized fluctuations even uncoupled systems.
code: # Correlated noise with no cross-regulation gamma_2d <- matrix(c(   1, 0.5,   0.5, 1 ), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE)  model_2d <- affectOU(theta = 0.5, mu = 0, gamma = gamma_2d) sim_2d <- simulate(model_2d, seed = 102) plot(sim_2d, by_dim = FALSE, main = "Correlated Noise", xlim = c(0, 20)) plot(sim_2d, type = "phase", main = "Phase Portrait")

title: Simulate Affect Dynamics with Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Processes
text: aim affectOU provide tools simulating analyzing Ornstein-Uhlenbeck (OU) process R. OU process models variables change time influenced random perturbations. widely used model affect dynamics psychology, formulating three core psychological mechanisms (assuming unidimensional process simplicity): Œ∏ (theta): emotion regulation capacity Governs rate affect returns baseline. Low Œ∏ indicates emotional inertia rumination; high Œ∏ indicates rapid regulation. Œº (mu): affective set point long-term average level affect system tends return . represent individual‚Äôs baseline mood emotional equilibrium. Œ≥ (gamma): emotional reactivity Controls magnitude short-term fluctuations noise affective system. can interpreted individual‚Äôs sensitivity environmental perturbations. affectOU serves demonstration package computational models, detailed Evers & Vanhasbroeck (2026), ‚ÄúSharing Computational Models Reproducible User-Friendly Packages: Tutorial R‚Äù (forthcoming).

what: affectOU: Simulate Affect Dynamics with Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Processes ‚Äî affectOU-package
title: affectOU: Simulate Affect Dynamics with Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Processes ‚Äî affectOU-package
text: Simulate multivariate Ornstein-Uhlenbeck (OU) process model psychological affect dynamics. OU process continuous-time stochastic process simulated using Euler-Maruyama discretization. models affect self-regulating system three psychologically meaningful parameters: theta quantifies emotion regulation capacity (quickly affect returns baseline; lower values indicate emotional inertia rumination); mu represents person's affective set point typical mood state; gamma captures emotional reactivity (strongly affect responds ongoing fluctuations). OU can visualised using time trajectories, histograms, autocorrelation functions, phase plots. package supports fitting univariate OU models data, also provides theoretical properties OU. References: Uhlenbeck & Ornstein (1930) doi:10.1103/PhysRev.36.823 ; Oravecz, Tuerlinckx & Vandekerckhove (2009) doi:10.1007/s11336-008-9106-8 ; Kuppens, Allen & Sheeber (2010) doi:10.1177/0956797610372634 ; Kuppens, Oravecz & Tuerlinckx (2010) doi:10.1037/a0020962 .

title: Create Ornstein-Uhlenbeck affect model ‚Äî affectOU
code: affectOU(   ndim = 1,   theta = 0.5,   mu = 0,   gamma = 1,   sigma = gamma %*% t(gamma),   initial_state = mu )

title: Create Ornstein-Uhlenbeck affect model ‚Äî affectOU
text: ndim Dimensionality affect process. Defaults 1 (univariate). needs specified inferred dimensions parameters. theta Attractor strength (rate return baseline). 1D: positive scalar. multidimensional: square matrix. mu Attractor location (baseline affect / set point). 1D: scalar. multidimensional: vector. non-stationary models: \(\theta < 0\), process pushed away \(\mu\) rather toward ; \(\theta \approx 0\), \(\mu\) meaningful influence trajectory. gamma Diffusion coefficient (multiplies \(dW(t)\) SDE). 1D: positive scalar. multidimensional: matrix. Either gamma sigma must specified, . gamma specified, sigma computed \(\Sigma = \Gamma\Gamma^\top\). sigma Noise covariance matrix (\(\Sigma = \Gamma\Gamma^\top\)). 1D: positive scalar (variance). multidimensional: positive semi-definite matrix. -diagonal elements represent correlated noise dimensions. Either gamma sigma must specified, . sigma specified, gamma computed via Cholesky decomposition. initial_state Starting value affect. 1D: scalar. multidimensional: vector. Defaults mu.

title: Create Ornstein-Uhlenbeck affect model ‚Äî affectOU
text: object class affectOU, representing univariate multivariate Ornstein‚ÄìUhlenbeck (OU) affect regulation model. object list following components: parameters named list model parameters: theta Numeric matrix. Mean reversion / regulation strength. mu Numeric vector. Attractor location / affective set point. gamma Numeric matrix. Diffusion coefficient (multiplies dW(t)). sigma Numeric matrix. Noise covariance (\(\Sigma = \Gamma\Gamma'\)). initial_state Numeric vector indicating starting value affect process used simulation. ndim Integer indicating dimensionality process.

title: Create Ornstein-Uhlenbeck affect model ‚Äî affectOU
text: Continuous-time stochastic differential equation model affect regulation. OU process models affect mean-reverting process : $$dX(t) = \theta(\mu - X(t))dt + \gamma dW(t)$$ 1D case, $$dX(t) = \Theta(\mu - X(t))dt + \Gamma dW(t)$$ multidimensional case. : \(\theta / \Theta\) (theta): attractor strength / regulation speed (scalar matrix) \(\mu\) (mu): attractor location / set point (scalar vector) \(\gamma / \Gamma\) (gamma): diffusion coefficient multiplies dW(t) \(\sigma / \Sigma\) (sigma): noise covariance matrix, computed \(\Sigma = \Gamma\Gamma'\) Different \(\Gamma\) matrices yield \(\Sigma\) produce statistically identical processes, \(\Sigma\) (\(\Gamma\)) determines model's behaviour. multidimensional case, element \(\Theta_{ij}\) (row \(\), column \(j\)) represents influence dimension \(j\) dimension \(\)'s drift. Specifically, drift dimension \(\) \(\sum_j \Theta_{ij}(\mu_j - X_j)\): Diagonal elements \(\Theta_{ii}\): self-regulation (fast dimension \(\) returns attractor \(\mu_i\)). Positive values necessary self-regulation, strong cross-regulation can override destabilise system (see summary() system-level stability checks). -diagonal elements \(\Theta_{ij}\) \(\neq j\): cross-regulation (dimension \(j\) influences dimension \(\)). \(\Theta_{ij} > 0\), dimension \(j\) attractor positive influence dimension \(\) (pulls ); \(\Theta_{ij} < 0\), dimension \(j\) attractor negative influence dimension \(\) (pushes ).

title: Create Ornstein-Uhlenbeck affect model ‚Äî affectOU
text: Oravecz, Z., Tuerlinckx, F., & Vandekerckhove, J. (2011). hierarchical latent stochastic differential equation model affective dynamics. Psychological Methods, 16(4), 468-490.

title: Create Ornstein-Uhlenbeck affect model ‚Äî affectOU
code: # 1D model model_1d <- affectOU(theta = 0.5, mu = 0, gamma = 1) summary(model_1d) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ 1D Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Dynamics ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> Stable (node) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Stationary distribution ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> Mean: 0 #> SD: 1 #> Half-life: 1.386 #> Relaxation time (œÑ): 2 coef(model_1d) #> $theta #> [1] 0.5 #>  #> $mu #> [1] 0 #>  #> $gamma #> [1] 1 #>  #> $sigma #> [1] 1 #>   # 2D model (uncoupled) model_2d <- affectOU(   ndim = 2, theta = diag(c(0.5, 0.3)), mu = 0,   gamma = 1 ) summary(model_2d) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ 2D Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Dynamics ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> Stable (node) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Stationary distribution ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> Mean: [0, 0] #> SD: [1, 1.291] #> Half-life: [1.386, 2.31] #> Relaxation time (œÑ): [2, 3.333] #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Structure ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> Coupling: none #> Noise: independent  # Simulate trajectory sim <- simulate(model_2d, stop = 100, save_at = 0.1) plot(sim)   # 3D model (coupled) theta_3d <- matrix(c(   0.5, 0.1, 0,   0.1, 0.3, 0.05,   0, 0.05, 0.4 ), nrow = 3) model_3d <- affectOU(   ndim = 3, theta = theta_3d,   mu = 0, gamma = 1 ) summary(model_3d) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ 3D Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Dynamics ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> Stable (node) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Stationary distribution ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> Mean: [0, 0, 0] #> SD: [1.036, 1.351, 1.131] #> Half-life: [1.53, 2.605, 1.788] #> Relaxation time (œÑ): [2.24, 3.796, 2.59] #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Structure ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> Coupling: Dim 1 ‚Üí Dim 2 (+), Dim 2 ‚Üí Dim 1 (+), Dim 2 ‚Üí Dim 3 (+), Dim 3 ‚Üí Dim #> 2 (+) #> Noise: independent  # Simulate trajectory sim_3d <- simulate(model_3d, stop = 100, save_at = 0.1) plot(sim_3d)

title: Plot autocorrelation and cross-correlation functions ‚Äî ou_plot_acf
text: univariate OU process, autocorrelation lag \(\tau\) : $$\rho(\tau) = e^{-\theta \tau}$$ ACF decays exponentially rate \(\theta\)‚Äîrate governing perturbation decay toward attractor. lag equal half-life (\(\log(2)/\theta\)), ACF equals 0.5. Faster decay means less predictability time. multivariate processes, diagonal panels show ACF dimension, -diagonal panels show cross-correlation function (CCF) dimension pairs, can non-zero even lag 0 dimensions correlated equilibrium.

title: Plot autocorrelation and cross-correlation functions ‚Äî ou_plot_acf
code: model <- affectOU(ndim = 2) sim <- simulate(model, nsim = 3) ou_plot_acf(sim)   # ACF at half-life equals 0.5 model <- affectOU(theta = 0.5, mu = 0, gamma = 1) sim <- simulate(model, stop = 500, dt = 0.01, save_at = 0.01) ou_plot_acf(sim, lag.max = 5) abline(v = log(2) / 0.5, col = "red", lty = 2) # half-life abline(h = 0.5, col = "red", lty = 2)

title: Plot simulation histogram ‚Äî ou_plot_histogram
text: system stable (\(\theta > 0\)), stationary distribution normal mean \(\mu\) variance \(\gamma^2 / (2\theta)\). theoretical density curve overlaid histogram system stationary. Different parameter combinations can yield stationary variance produce different dynamics. example, doubling \(\theta\) \(\gamma\) keeps stationary SD constant changes half-life.

title: Plot simulation histogram ‚Äî ou_plot_histogram
code: model <- affectOU(ndim = 2) sim <- simulate(model, nsim = 3) ou_plot_histogram(sim)   # Plot dimensions in one panel sim <- simulate(model, nsim = 1) ou_plot_histogram(sim, by_dim = FALSE)   # Same stationary SD, different dynamics m1 <- affectOU(theta = 0.5, mu = 0, gamma = 1) # SD = 1, half-life = 1.4 m2 <- affectOU(theta = 2.0, mu = 0, gamma = 2) # SD = 1, half-life = 0.35 s1 <- simulate(m1, stop = 100) s2 <- simulate(m2, stop = 100) ou_plot_histogram(s1, main = "Slow regulation")  ou_plot_histogram(s2, main = "Fast regulation")

title: Plot phase portrait ‚Äî ou_plot_phase
text: NULL (invisibly), called side effects

title: Plot phase portrait ‚Äî ou_plot_phase
text: diagonal panels plot \(X_i(t)\) \(X_i(t + \Delta t)\), showing relationship current next value dimension. system stable (\(\theta_{ii} > 0\)), conditional expectation : $$E[X_i(t + \Delta t) \mid X_i(t) = x] = \mu_i + (x - \mu_i)e^{-\theta_{ii} \Delta t}$$ line \((\mu_i, \mu_i)\) slope \(e^{-\theta_{ii} \Delta t} < 1\). slope less 1 reflects mean reversion: values \(\mu_i\) expected decrease; values \(\mu_i\) expected increase. star marks attractor point \((\mu_i, \mu_i)\). theoretical line drawn system stable.

title: Plot phase portrait ‚Äî ou_plot_phase
text: -diagonal panels plot \(X_i(t)\) \(X_j(t)\) time point, showing joint distribution dimensions \(\) \(j\). system stable, conditional expectation based stationary covariance \(\Gamma_\infty\) : $$E[X_j \mid X_i = x] = \mu_j + \frac{\Gamma_{\infty,ij}}{\Gamma_{\infty,ii}}(x - \mu_i)$$ regression line \((\mu_i, \mu_j)\) slope determined stationary covariance structure. theoretical line drawn system stable.

title: Plot phase portrait ‚Äî ou_plot_phase
code: model <- affectOU(ndim = 2) sim <- simulate(model, nsim = 3) ou_plot_phase(sim)   # Mean reversion visible in slope < 1 model <- affectOU(theta = 0.5, mu = 0, gamma = 1) sim <- simulate(model, stop = 100, dt = 0.01, save_at = 0.1) ou_plot_phase(sim) # slope = exp(-0.5 * 0.1) = 0.95

title: Compute relaxation time for OU model ‚Äî relaxation.affectOU
text: relaxation time \(\tau = 1/\theta_{ii}\) characteristic time scale OU process.  measures quickly process "forgets" current state returns toward equilibrium. half-life \(t_{1/2} = \ln 2 \cdot \tau\) reported alongside. Relaxation time defined stable dimensions (\(\theta_{ii} > 0\)). Dimensions \(\theta_{ii} \le 0\) (random walk unstable node) return NA.

Default NULL, computes dimensions. method Method compute relaxation time: "analytic" (uses \(1/\theta_{ii}\), valid diagonal theta), "numeric" (finds root \(\mathrm{ACF} - 1/e\)), "auto" (uses analytic theta diagonal, otherwise numeric).  Default "auto". ... Additional arguments (unused).

title: Compute relaxation time for OU model ‚Äî relaxation.affectOU
text: object class relaxation_affectOU. single dimension requested, list : relaxation_time relaxation time \(\tau\) (NA dimension stable) half_life half-life \(t_{1/2}\) (NA dimension stable) dimension dimension index method Method used ("analytic", "numeric", NA) theta_ii Diagonal element theta dimension ndim Dimensionality process multiple dimensions requested, data frame columns: dimension, relaxation_time, half_life, theta_ii, method, ndim.

title: Compute relaxation time for OU model ‚Äî relaxation.affectOU
text: Starting \(x_0\), expected trajectory 1D OU process : $$E[X(t)] = \mu + (x_0 - \mu)\,e^{-\theta t}$$ deviation baseline decays exponentially.  relaxation time point fraction \(1/e \approx 36.8\%\) initial deviation remains: $$\tau = \frac{1}{\theta}$$ half-life point 50\ $$t_{1/2} = \ln 2 \cdot \tau = \frac{\ln 2}{\theta}   \approx \frac{0.693}{\theta}$$

title: Compute relaxation time for OU model ‚Äî relaxation.affectOU
text: diagonal \(\Theta\) (uncoupled dimensions), dimension analytic relaxation time \(1/\theta_{ii}\). non-diagonal \(\Theta\) (coupled dimensions), cross-regulation alters effective relaxation rate. relaxation time computed numerically finding theoretical autocorrelation function crosses \(1/e\) (\(0.5\) half-life). Coupling can either speed slow relaxation compared uncoupled case.

title: Compute relaxation time for OU model ‚Äî relaxation.affectOU
text: uncoupled systems (diagonal \(\Theta\)), \(\gamma\) affects amplitude fluctuations (stationary variance), relaxation time scale. ACF \(e^{-\theta_{ii}\tau}\), stationary variance cancels. coupled systems, \(\gamma\) influence relaxation time stationary covariance \(\Sigma_\infty\) (depends \(\Sigma\)) enters matrix-exponential ACF longer cancels.

title: Compute relaxation time for OU model ‚Äî relaxation.affectOU
code: # 1D stable model <- affectOU(theta = 0.5) relaxation(model) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Relaxation time of 1D Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> Half-life (t‚ÇÅ/‚ÇÇ): 1.386 time units #> Relaxation time (œÑ): 2 time units #>  #> Time for perturbation to decay to: #>      50%     37%     14%      5%      1% #>    1.386   2.000   4.000   6.000  10.000  # 1D random walk model_rw <- affectOU(theta = 0) relaxation(model_rw) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Relaxation time of 1D Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> Relaxation time: undefined (not stable)  # 2D mixed: one stable node, one unstable node model_mixed <- affectOU(theta = diag(c(0.5, -0.3))) relaxation(model_mixed)$relaxation_time #> [1]  2 NA  # Diagonal vs coupled: coupling changes relaxation times model_uncoupled <- affectOU(theta = diag(c(0.5, 0.2)), mu = 0, gamma = 1) relaxation(model_uncoupled)$relaxation_time #> [1] 2 5  theta_coupled <- matrix(c(0.5, 0.0, 0.3, 0.5), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE) model_coupled <- update(model_uncoupled, theta = theta_coupled) relaxation(model_coupled)$relaxation_time #> [1] 2.000000 2.326722

title: Simulation in Evers & Vanhasbroeck (2026) ‚Äî simpaper
text: process defined stochastic differential equation: $$d\mathbf{X}_t = \boldsymbol{\Theta}(\boldsymbol{\mu} - \mathbf{X}_t)dt + \boldsymbol{\Gamma}^{1/2}d\mathbf{W}_t$$ : \(\boldsymbol{\Theta} = \begin{pmatrix} 0.7 & 0 \\ 0 & 0.3 \end{pmatrix}\) drift matrix \(\boldsymbol{\mu} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}\) equilibrium mean vector \(\boldsymbol{\Gamma} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\) diffusion matrix \(\mathbf{W}_t\) two-dimensional Wiener process

text: list class stability_affectOU containing: is_stable Logical, TRUE system stable (eigenvalues positive real parts) dynamics Character string describing dynamics type using dynamical systems terminology. 1D: "stable node", "random walk", "unstable node". multivariate: "stable node", "stable spiral", "unstable node", "unstable spiral", "marginally stable", "saddle point", "saddle spiral". per_dimension Character vector per-dimension dynamics classification (NULL 1D) eigenvalues Eigenvalues theta ndim Dimensionality process

title: Assess stability of an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck model ‚Äî stability.affectOU
text: Note although typically, system stable eigenvalues negative real parts, due parameterization OU process, stability determined positive real parts: $$dX(t) = \Theta(\mu - X(t))dt + \Gamma dW(t)$$ \(\Theta\) multiplied negative state variable, positive eigenvalues indicate deviations attractor decay time, leading stable system. Conversely, negative eigenvalues indicate deviations grow time, leading unstable system.

title: Assess stability of an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck model ‚Äî stability.affectOU
text: stationary distribution exists eigenvalues \(\Theta\) positive real parts. system-level property, per-dimension property: Positive diagonal elements (\(\Theta_{ii} > 0\)) alone guarantee stability. Strong -diagonal coupling can push eigenvalues toward zero negative real parts, destabilising system. Conversely, coupling dimensions can stabilise dimension whose diagonal element small even zero. dimension non-stationary isolation may become stationary embedded coupled system.

title: Assess stability of an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck model ‚Äî stability.affectOU
text: Complex eigenvalues (arising asymmetric coupling) produce oscillatory dynamics, dimensions cycle around . eigenvalues positive real parts, oscillations damped system still converges \(\mu\). eigenvalue non-positive real part, oscillations grow system diverges.

title: Assess stability of an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck model ‚Äî stability.affectOU
text: System-level dynamics classified using dynamical systems terms: node converges diverges without oscillation, spiral exhibits damped growing oscillations, saddle point mixed convergence/divergence across directions. Per-dimension dynamics describe behavior dimension isolation based diagonal element \(\Theta\) ("stable node" positive, "random walk" zero, "unstable node" negative). dimension classified "stable node" isolation may still belong unstable coupled system due cross-regulation.

title: Assess stability of an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck model ‚Äî stability.affectOU
code: # 1D stable node model <- affectOU(theta = 0.5, mu = 0, gamma = 1) stability(model) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Stability analysis of 1D Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> Stable (node). Deviations from the attractor decay exponentially.  # 1D random walk (not stable) model_rw <- affectOU(theta = 0) stability(model_rw) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Stability analysis of 1D Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> Not stable (random walk). No attractor; the process drifts freely.  # Positive diagonals with oscillatory coupling: stable theta_osc <- matrix(c(0.5, -0.4, 0.4, 0.5), nrow = 2) eigen(theta_osc)$values # complex with positive real part #> [1] 0.5+0.4i 0.5-0.4i stability(affectOU(theta = theta_osc, mu = 0, gamma = 1)) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Stability analysis of 2D Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> Stable (spiral). The system spirals toward the attractor with damped #> oscillations.  # Strong coupling still stable if real parts stay positive theta_strong <- matrix(c(0.5, -1.5, 1.5, 0.5), nrow = 2) stability(affectOU(theta = theta_strong, mu = 0, gamma = 1)) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Stability analysis of 2D Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> Stable (spiral). The system spirals toward the attractor with damped #> oscillations.  # All diagonals positive, but coupling destabilises the system theta_destab <- matrix(c(0.5, 1.0, 1.0, 0.5), nrow = 2) stability(affectOU(theta = theta_destab, mu = 0, gamma = 1)) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Stability analysis of 2D Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> Not stable (saddle point). Some directions converge while others diverge.  # One negative diagonal element makes the system non-stationary theta_unstable <- matrix(c(0.5, 0, 0, -0.3), nrow = 2) stability(affectOU(theta = theta_unstable, mu = 0, gamma = 1))$is_stable #> [1] FALSE

title: Compute stationary distribution for Ornstein-Uhlenbeck model ‚Äî stationary.affectOU
text: \(\theta > 0\) (1D) eigenvalues \(\Theta\) positive real parts (multivariate), process converges stationary distribution: $$X_\infty \sim N\!\left(\mu,\; \frac{\gamma^2}{2\theta}\right)$$ stationary variance \(\gamma^2/(2\theta)\) depends \(\gamma\) \(\theta\). Different parameter combinations can produce long-run spread different dynamics (see examples).

title: Compute stationary distribution for Ornstein-Uhlenbeck model ‚Äî stationary.affectOU
text: multivariate models, stationary covariance matrix \(\Sigma_\infty\) solves Lyapunov equation: $$\Theta \Sigma_\infty + \Sigma_\infty \Theta^\top = \Sigma$$ \(\Sigma = \Gamma\Gamma^\top\) noise covariance. -diagonal elements \(\Theta\) (cross-regulation) can induce correlation equilibrium even noise independent.

title: Compute stationary distribution for Ornstein-Uhlenbeck model ‚Äî stationary.affectOU
text: Key theoretical quantities 1D case: Stationary properties depend \(\gamma\) \(\theta\); temporal dynamics depend mainly \(\theta\). Two processes can share stationary distributions differ dynamics, vice versa.

title: Compute stationary distribution for Ornstein-Uhlenbeck model ‚Äî stationary.affectOU
code: # 1D model model <- affectOU(theta = 0.5, mu = 0, gamma = 1) stationary(model) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Stationary distribution of 1D Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> Mean: 0 #> SD: 1 #> 95% interval: [-2, 2]  # All components unclass(stationary(model)) #> $is_stable #> [1] TRUE #>  #> $mean #> [1] 0 #>  #> $sd #> [1] 1 #>  #> $cov #> NULL #>  #> $cor #> NULL #>  #> $ndim #> [1] 1 #>   # Different dynamics, same stationary distribution model_slow <- affectOU(theta = 0.5, mu = 0, gamma = 1) model_fast <- affectOU(theta = 2.0, mu = 0, gamma = 2) stationary(model_slow)$sd #> [1] 1 stationary(model_fast)$sd #> [1] 1  # Non-stable model model_rw <- affectOU(theta = 0) stationary(model_rw) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Stationary distribution of 1D Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> Does not exist (system is not stable).  # 2D: coupling induces stationary correlation theta_2d <- matrix(c(0.5, 0.0, 0.3, 0.5), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE) model_2d <- affectOU(ndim = 2, theta = theta_2d, mu = 0, gamma = 1) stationary(model_2d)$cor # non-zero off-diagonal #>            [,1]       [,2] #> [1,]  1.0000000 -0.2761724 #> [2,] -0.2761724  1.0000000

code: model <- affectOU(theta = 0.5, mu = 0, gamma = 1) sim <- simulate(model, stop = 500, dt = 0.01, save_at = 0.1) data <- as.data.frame(sim) fitted <- fit(model, data = data$value, times = data$time) summary(fitted) #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Fitted Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model Summary ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ #> Method: mle, 5001 observations #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Coefficients ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #>       Estimate    SE          95% CI #> theta    0.510 0.046  [0.419, 0.600] #> mu      -0.055 0.089 [-0.229, 0.119] #> gamma    1.012 0.010  [0.991, 1.032] #>  #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Goodness of fit ‚îÄ‚îÄ #>  #> Log-likelihood: -1269.192 #> RMSE: 0.312
